She therefore has plans to expand the business and install a small sewing workshop to make clothing at home.  This will be MFP loan #6 and she feels grateful for the financial support she’s been getting and wants to continue with it so she commits to make her payments like she’s done previously.

She will use the requested 1,200 new soles to buy sewing supplies like fabric and thread to make lingerie; she will seek out the lowest prices for volume purchases so her profits will be higher.

loans.use: to buy fabric and thread.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages.

loans.name: Nikki

texts.en:
Nikki is 43 years old and she is from Tudela, Misamis Occidental.  She is married and has one child. 

To earn a living, Nikki runs a general store.  She has been in business for four years and earns approximately 4,600 PHP each month.  Nikki is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase additional products like canned goods, noodles, sugar and coffee.  

Nikki joined GDMPC in 2010.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from this loan to save as a reserve for future emergencies.

loans.use: to purchase additional products like canned goods, noodles, sugar and coffee.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks, and beverages for her shop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy 30 pagnes (traditional cloths)

loans.name: Celia

texts.es:
Celia, de 42 años de edad, es una mujer  trabajadora y empeñosa, además  de ser amable y religioso.  Es conviviente  con Rony quien se dedica al comercio y es padre de sus 6 hijos a quienes quiere mucho y son su motivación. Vive en compañía de su pareja  e hijos, habitando su propia casa que logró construir con el apoyo de su pareja. La actividad que realiza Celia  es la venta de mercadería variada como ropas, zapatos, sandalias, pasamanerías y otro. Todos estos productos los compra en los centros comerciales de la localidad, y los vende en los caseríos ubicados a la rivera de los ríos, realizando viajes periódicos a esa zona.  Ofreciendo y vendiendo muy amablemente a sus clientes
Este negocio viene funcionando desde hace 05  años, iniciándose con un capital propio  luego fue creciendo con préstamos de MFP, con el apoyo de su pareja en la comercialización de sus productos.
Considera a su negocio bastante rentable por las buenas ganancias que le deja y el lograr vender todo el producto que lleva por los caseríos.
Le gusta su actividad ya que la mantienen  ocupada, y le permite visitar a su madre que vive en el caserío que visita, gracias a ello le genera un ingreso económico para solventara sus gastos propios y la educación de sus hijos a quienes quiere mucho. Pero comenta que es un negocio con bastante desgaste físico y no le permite estar el tiempo suficiente con sus hijos. Por tal motivo desea dejar negocio e incursionar en otro, pero desde la comodidad de su casa como una tienda de comestibles. Por tanto éste será el préstamo número 09 con la institución MFP, se siente agradecida con el apoyo financiero que viene recibiendo para avanzar con su negocio. Por tal motivo se compromete a ser responsable con el pago de sus cuotas como en los créditos anteriores. Por otro lado se siente a gusto con su banco comunal pues considera a sus miembros ser personas responsables.
Con el monto solicitado de 1000 nuevos soles, los invertirá en la compra mercadería variada para llevarlo por os caseríos, como linternas, pilas, ropas, productos de belleza y otros, buscando precios más cómodos por sus compras al contando, así tendrá un stock disponible para la venta.
texts.en:
Celia, 42, is a hardworking, dedicated woman in addition to being kind and gracious.  She lives with Rony who is a merchant and father of their six children who she loves very much and are her motivating force.  She lives with her spouse and children in her house that she and her spouse built.  Celia’s activity is selling varied merchandise like clothes, shoes, sandals, notions and others.  She buys all her merchandise in local shopping centers and sells them in settlements along river banks making periodic trips to that zone to kindly offer and sell to her customers.  The business has been in operation five years having started it with capital of her own and then growing with MFP loans and with her spouse’s help with the sales.  She considers it to be quite profitable because of the good profits it yields and because she manages to sell out everything she takes to the settlements.

She likes her activity because it keeps her busy and allows her to visit her mother who lives in the settlement she visits.  Thanks to it she generates income to cover her own expenses and her children’s schooling who she loves very much.  She comments though that this business is quite physically demanding and does not leave her enough time to spend with her children.  Because of this, she’s planning to leave this business and go into a new one but something she can do from the comfort of home like a grocery store.  

This will be MFP loan #9.  She feels grateful for the financial support she’s been getting to advance with her business and because of that she commits to be responsible with her installment payments like she’s been previously.  Also, she feels comfortable in her communal bank because the members are responsible people.  She will use the requested 1,000 new soles to buy varied merchandise like flashlights, batteries, clothes and beauty products to take to the settlements seeking out the lowest prices for cash purchases in order to have stock available for sale.

loans.use: to buy flashlights, batteries, clothes and beauty supplies.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy fresh foods and vegetables

loans.name: Happy Friends Development Group

texts.en:
Using the previous loan, Charles was able to raise his income since his harvest increased as a result of a bigger cultivated field and the ability to hire more labor. He has used some of the money from the harvest sales to rent a stall where he stocks his goods when he brings them to the city to sell.

Juliana, another member of the group, is a 34-year-old single mother who is hardworking and creative. She was divorced by her husband who left her for another woman. Juliana then resorted to selling charcoal to get some money to look after her children and dependents. She now wants a loan to buy wood, which she will sell in order to get school fees for her five children (a sixth child will start school next year). Juliana is challenged by stiff competition, weather changes and the tough economic times, especially now when she is the sole breadwinner for a large family. Her dream is to build a house that she and the children will call theirs.
The 10th person in the picture seated at the extreme right is the UGAFODE staff.

loans.use: to buy seeds and to hire labour.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more recyclable materials to resell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.

loans.name: Fely

texts.en: Fely is from Poblacion 3, Clarin. She is 46 years old. Fely is married and has four children. To make a living, Fely is operating a general store. Due to a lack of products to sell, Fely is asking for a loan from GDMPC amounting to 10,000 PHP to purchase additional products like canned goods, noodles, sugar and coffee. Fely has been in business for nine years and earns 4,000 PHP a month from these activities. Recently this year, Fely joined GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated as a result of the loan to make improvements to her house.

loans.use: to purchase additional products like canned goods, noodles, sugar and coffee.

loans.name: Julita

texts.en:
Julita is a 64-year-old farmer from Ubay, Bohol. She and her husband have been rice farmers for several years now, and this is the source of their income. 

Julita is asking for a loan to buy seedlings, fertilizer, and pesticides for the farm. These items will help Julita and her husband to enhance their farm and produce a good harvest.

In the future, Julita hopes to expand her farming business so that it will generate more revenue to meet the needs of her family.

loans.use: to buy seedlings, fertilizer, and pesticides for her farm.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is married and has three children. She is 29 years old and resides in Canicapan, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. Jocelyn owns and operates a farm, planting and harvesting bananas. She's been doing this for eight years. Each month, she earns 4,000 PHP. 

Jocelyn has requested a loan of 7,000 PHP to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young plants to raise. In 2011, Jocelyn joined GDMPC. In the future, she wants to make improvements to her house and to improve the living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young plants to raise.

loans.name: Divina

texts.en:
Divina is a hard-working entrepreneur who has a music rental business in the Philippines. She is borrowing 29500 PHP through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) to purchase an additional unit of musical instruments for her music rental business.

Divina has been in this business for ten years. She earns more income from fish-vending.

Divina has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts, with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving enough money, so she can afford to send her children to college in the future.

loans.use: to purchase an additional unit of musical instruments for her business.

loans.name: Julienne

texts.fr: Revendeuse d’ustensiles de cuisine et de pagnes à domicile, Julienne a pour mari un infirmier, elle a un enfant âgé de 28ans qui ne va plus à l’école. Elle est âgée de 45ans. Elle fait son premier crédit à WAGES pour acheter des ustensiles de cuisine et des pagnes afin de revendre aux clients et tirer de bénéfice. Ses achats se font au Grand marché et au Port autonome de Lomé. Avec les profits qu’elle va tirer de ses ventes, elle veut construire une boutique devant sa maison et prendre  soin de sa famille.
texts.en: Julienne sells kitchen utensils and pagnes (traditional cloths) from her home. Her husband is a nurse and she has a 28 year old child who no longer goes to school. She is 45 years old. She is requesting her first loan from the microfinance institution WAGES so that she can buy kitchen utensils and traditional cloths that she can sell to her customers for a profit. She gets her supplies from the Great market at the Autonomous Port of Lomé. Thanks to the profits that she will make from her business, she would like to build a store in front of her house and take care of her family.

loans.use: to buy kitchen utensils and pagnes (traditional cloths)

loans.name: Prosperidad Y Exito Group

texts.es:
¡Saludos  desde Perú! Este es el grupo Prosperidad y Éxito 
El grupo está formado por 09 socias una de ellas es Rita de 47 años. Ella es casada y tiene 02 hijas, una de 23 años y la ultima de 18; ambas estudian en la universidad. Rita se dedica a la venta de ropa, calzado y diferentes artículos de vestir, gracias a su trabajo puede seguir apoyando a sus hijas con los gastos de sus estudios. Rita tiene muchos clientes que son sus fieles compradores ella los visita en sus casas para ofrecer y tomar sus pedidos, sus mejores clientes  son en su mayoría mujeres quienes le solicitan carteras y calzado, debido a la demanda que tiene usara su préstamo para comprar estos productos, las fiestas navideñas es una buena oportunidad para las ventas,  por eso quiere abastecerse con diferentes artículos, su mayor deseo es tener una tienda propia para ofrecer sus productos directamente al público.
 Rita quiere decir ¡Muchas gracias! a todos los inversionistas de todo el mundo por su préstamo y por apoyar a su grupo, en la foto es  la segunda de la izquierda viste pantalón jean y polo negro.
texts.en: Greetings from Peru!  This is the “Prosperidad y Éxito” (Prosperity and Success) group.  It has 9 members.  One of them is Rita, 47, who is married and has two daughters, a 23-year-old and an 18-year-old; both attend university.  Rita works selling clothes, footwear and various items of clothing.  Thanks to her work she’s able to continue to support her daughters with their schooling costs.  Rita has many regular customers who faithfully buy from her.  She visits them at home to offer her wares and take their orders.  Her best customers are for the most part women who request purses and shoes.  Because of the demand her products have she will use the loan to buy them because the Christmas season is a good time for sales and she wants to stock up with various items.  Her greatest wish is to have a store of her own to sell her products directly to the public.  Rita would like to say: Many Thanks to all the lenders world-wide for her loan and for supporting her group.  In the photo, she’s second from the left, wearing jeans and a black shirt.

loans.use: to buy purses and shoes.

loans.name: Amigas Unidas Group

texts.es:
María es uno de los miembros del Grupo Amigas Unidas

María tiene 50 años es madre de 04 hijos de los cuales 03 son mayores de edad, su esposo es quien mantiene el hogar y gracias a su trabajo ella también colabora con algunos gastos. María  tiene su negocio de venta de dulces entre los que ofrece miel de abeja, turrones y diferentes golosinas, cuando empezó su negocio solo contaba con algunos productos pero poco a poco fue mejorando y en la actualidad su negocio ha crecido, permitiéndole ayudar en los estudios de sus hijos. María trabaja de lunes a domingo recorriendo diferentes mercados de su zona para ofrecer sus productos, durante todo este tiempo ya es conocida y tiene mucha clientela, el dinero de su préstamo  será para comprar dulces y golosinas por cantidades y así poder atender los pedidos de sus clientes, mas adelante desea tener su propia tienda para no tener que caminar tanto.
María esta feliz por el apoyo que recibe y por saber que muchas personas que no conoce confían en ella y su grupo.
María es la primera de la izquierda viste polo rosado y pantalon marron tiene puesta una cartera azul.
texts.en:
María is one of the members of the “Amigas Unidas” (United Girlfriends) group.  She’s 50-years-old and the mother of four children three of which are adults.  Her husband supports the home but thanks to her work she’s also able to contribute towards some of the expenses.  

María has a business selling sweets.  Among those she sells are honey, nougat and various snacks.  When she started her business she only had a few products but gradually she improved and now the business has grown and she’s able to help pay for her children’s schooling.

María works Monday through Sunday going to various markets in her area offering her products.  In all this time she’s become well-known and has many customers.  She will use the money from her loan to buy candy and sweets in quantity to be able to fill customer orders.  Later on she’d like to have her own store to not have to walk so much any longer. 

María is happy about the support she gets and for knowing that so many people she doesn't even know trust her and her group.  María is first on the left wearing a pink shirt and brown pants; she’s carrying a blue purse.

loans.use: to buy candy and snacks.

loans.name: Ketia

texts.es: Doña Ketia, 41 años de edad, soltera, se dedica a la venta de ganado. Ella con ayuda de su compañero y cuñado desde hace 10 años están con la crianza y venta de terneros. Ella desea este crédito para generar ingresos al hogar y ahorrar para la operación de uno de sus hijos. Esto le ayuda para el crecimiento personal, Ketia decidió solicitar un crédito en Fundación Mujer porque brindan un buen servicio. En un futuro desea continuar con la venta de ganado y aumentar sus ventas.
texts.en: Ketia, 41, is single and works selling cattle.  With help from her spouse and brother-in-law she’s been raising and selling calves for ten years.  She wants this loan to generate household income and to save up for an operation for one of her children. This will help in her personal growth.  Ketia decided to ask Fundación Mujer for a loan because they provide good service.  In future she’d like to continue selling cattle and increasing her sales.

loans.use: to buy calves to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy onions to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay maintenance costs.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks, and beverages.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy fish for processing and selling.

loans.name: La Ilusiones Group

texts.es:
Este Banco Comunal se llama “Las Ilusiones” está conformado por 16 emprendedores quienes se dedican a diferentes rubros, entre los cuales se encuentran ; venta de ropa, almacén, venta de articulos varios, venta de artesanía, venta de pan, servicios entre otros. Todos ellos pertenecientes a la ciudad de Villarrica.
Monica, integrante del grupo del Banco Comunal, quien en la foto se encuentra de pie en primera fila, ocupando el quinto lugar de derecha a izquierda, viste una chaqueta de color negra con gris, blue jeans, zapatos color café, su cabello es  castaño oscuro y lo usa tomado.
Ella se dedica  a la venta de ensaladas desde hace 3 meses. Comenta que ofrece sus ensaladas de casa en casa y con familiares, trabaja todos los días y su horario lo distribuye de acuerdo a su disponibilidad ya que sus hijos son pequeños.
La mercadería que va necesitando la compra en fruterías donde encuentra todo más fresco y a bajo costo por lo tanto conveniente económicamente.
Con el crédito comprará surtidos de ensaladas y algunos articulos para la temporada de navidad.
Una de las metas de Monica es tener un local establecido con todos los papeles al dia, y dar una buena atención a su clientela, y a la vez generar mayores ingresos para una mejor calidad de vida.
Monica vive junto a su marido y sus dos hijos de 2 y 5 años de edad. Sus sueños a nivel familiar darle un buen pasar a sus hijos, y a nivel laboral tener un local donde pueda vender mas cosas a parte de sus ensaladas.
Ella está muy agradecida y contenta por el apoyo brindado por Fondo Esperanza para invertir en su negocio. Además se siente muy cómoda con el grupo que participa, ya que en éste existe muy buena comunicación.
Villarrica es una  ciudad al sur de Chile, ubicada en la región de La Araucanía. Es una ciudad pequeña, pero cuenta con todos los servicios básicos y turísticos, siendo uno de los principales centros de servicios del área cordillerana y principal centro turístico de la región, junto con Pucón. Durante los meses de verano se realizan numerosas actividades y eventos culturales, artísticos y deportivos, Además de las innumerables alternativas de Ecoturismo, Turismo Aventura y Etnoturismo.
texts.en:
This communal bank is called “Las Ilusiones” and it has 16 members who are in different lines of work among which is clothing sales, store, assorted merchandise sales, bread sales and services, among others.  All are from the city of Villarrica.

Monica is a member of this communal bank and in the photo she’s standing in the first row, fifth from right to left, wearing a black and gray jacket, blue jeans, brown shoes; her hair is dark brown and she wears it up.

She has been selling salads for three months.  She comments that she sells them from house to house and to her family members.  She works every day and her work schedule is arranged according to her availability since her children are still little.

Merchandise she needs she buys in fruit stores where she finds everything fresher and at a lower price which is advantageous economically.  She will use the loan to buy an assortment of salads and some items for the Christmas season.

One of Monica’s goals is to have an established site with all permits up to date and to provide good customer service while generating higher income for a better quality of life.

Monica lives with her husband and two children who are 2 and 5 years old. Her dreams on a family level is to provide well for her children and on a work level is to have a site where she can sell other things besides salads.

She is very grateful and happy for the support provided by Fondo Esperanza to invest in her business; she also feels very comfortable in the group she’s part of because very good communication exists between them.

Villarrica is a city in south Chile located in the Araucanía region.  It’s a small city but it has all basic and tourism services.  It is one of the main service centers for the mountain region and main regional tourism center along with Pucón.  During the summer, numerous activities, cultural and artistic events and sporting events take place; it’s also home to innumerable ecotourism and extreme sport adventure options.

loans.use: to buy salads and some Christmas items.

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en:
This is Dolores, 44 and a resident of Manila, Philippines. She is married to Roger, an electrician, and is a mother to her children. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Dolores operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a 5 PHP worth of cooking oil or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue the operations of her business, she is requesting a 15,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Dolores dreams to give her children a good and quality education as well as hopes to expand her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, and this is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for the maintenance of the motorcycle.

loans.name: Ligaya

texts.en:
Ligaya is a 34-year-old married woman and a mother of six children from Ubay, Bohol. She has raised hogs for several years now.

Ligaya is asking for a loan to buy pigfeed and to construct an additional pigpen.

In the future, Ligaya dreams of expanding her business and saving money for the schooling of her children. Ligaya hopes to see her children become successful professionals someday.

loans.use: to buy pigfeed and build a pigpen.

loans.name: Ana

texts.en:
This is Ana. She previously accessed a 15,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase raw materials like fabric, thread, and other materials needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help in meeting her personal, household, and business expenses. In addition to her primary clothing manufacturing business, Ana also operates a tricycle for additional income.

Ana would like to apply for another 15,000 PHP loan to buy additional supplies like cloth, needles, fabric, and other materials. Her profits will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Ana hopes that her business will grow and succeed. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members every week to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration from studying the Word of God. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy cloth, needles, and other materials needed in her business.

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena is 42 years old and married with six children.

Elena works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a loan of 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) through the Negro Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) to buy additional items to sell, such as canned goods, noodles, spices, etc.

Elena has borrowed and repaid 29 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 10 years and also earns an income from coconut farming and food vending.

Elena aspires to save enough money so that she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell, such as canned goods, noodles, spices, etc.

loans.name: Cheryl

texts.en:
For over three years in Yahong, Tudela, Misamis Occidental, Cheryl, a 26-year-old married mother of one child, has made a living operating a general store, selling a variety of food and household products.  She earns 2,000 PHP each month for these activities.

Recently, Cheryl joined GDMPC.  She is now requesting a loan of 4,500 PHP in order to purchase new items such as candies, Milo (a brand of malted milk), shampoo, soaps, etc. to add to her inventory.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from this loan as a reserve for future emergencies.

loans.use: to purchase new items such as candies, Milo (malted milk), shampoo and soaps.

loans.name: Luisa

texts.en:
Luisa is a 61-year-old married woman and a mother of five grown-up children from Bohol, Philippines. Luisa runs a motorcycle repair and vulcanizing shop, a steel fabricating shop and a rice field. These are the sources of her income.

Luisa is asking for a loan to buy more steel for fabrication and farming materials like pesticides and fertilizer.

In the future, Luisa hopes of expanding her ventures to augment her income.

loans.use: to buy more steel for fabrication and farming materials

loans.name: Adolfa

texts.en:
Adolfa is a 55-year-old married woman with no children from Loboc, Bohol. She has been engaged in a piggery business for 5 years now by herself because her husband is a driver. This is the source of her income. She usually earns 8,000 PHP monthly.

Adolfa is requesting a loan to buy piglets and feeds. This loan will be use for the productivity of her business and to gain healthy pigs.  In the future, Adolfa dreams of expanding her business and becoming a successful businesswoman.

loans.use: to buy piglets and feeds

loans.name: Banco Mujer Creciendo Juntas Group

texts.es:
Mónica es una mujer  muy joven con  21 años de edad, es madre de un niño de 2 años, y tiene 4 años de vivir en unión libre. Tanto ella como su esposo trabajan muy duro para salir adelante como familia. El labora en una finca que cultiva piñas como peón agrícola, y  recibe un salario muy bajo, y ella se dedica a la cría de pollos  para ayudar con los gastos del hogar. Este es su tercer préstamo y los anteriores han sido de gran ayuda ya que le permitieron iniciar y consolidar su negocio, actualmente tiene una cantidad considerable de pollos, y va a incursionar también en la cría de cerdos, su plan de inversión es la compra de los animales, alimentos, vitaminas, concentrados, y otros. 
Esta mujer tan luchadora busca mejorar las condiciones de vida de ella y su familia, y su sueño es continuar estudiando y luego darle el estudio a su hijo. 
Junto a Mónica están 8 socias más que conforman Banco Mujer Creciendo Juntas, y las actividades a desarrollar son agropecuarias.
texts.en:
Mónica is a young woman just 21 years old.  She is the mother of a 2-year old son and has been living with her partner for four years.  Mónica and her husband work hard to help their family get ahead.  Her husband works on a pineapple farm as a farmhand and receives a very low salary.  Mónica raises chickens to help with the household expenses.  This is her third loan, and the previous ones have been a great help.  They allowed her to start up and strengthen her business.  She currently has a considerable number of chickens, and she is going to delve into raising pigs.  Her investment plan is to purchase the animals, animal feed, vitamins, concentrated feed and other items. 
This very determined woman is looking to improve her quality of life and that of her family.  Her dream is to continue her studies and later, to give her son an education. 
Eight members, together with Mónica, make up the communal bank "Banco Mujer Creciendo Juntas: (Women Growing Together Bank).  Their livelihoods come from agriculture and raising livestock.

loans.use: in the purchase of chickens, pigs, animal feed, concentrated feed, vitamins and other items.

loans.name: Paciana

texts.en:
Paciana is a 48-year-old married woman with five sons from Loboc, Bohol. She has been raising hogs for six years now; this is the source of her income of 12,000 PHP a month.

Paciana is requesting a loan to buy three piglets, four sacks of hog starter feed, and groceries. This loan will enable her to raise good, healthy piglets for sale.

In the future, Paciana hopes to expand her business and become a successful businesswoman.

loans.use: to buy piglets, pigfeed, and groceries.

loans.name: Huong

texts.en:
Huong is 55 years old and married. She has two son and lives with her family in Ho Chi Minh City. Huong has run a cafe at her house for 15 years, and her husband is a painter. 

Huong would like to take out a loan to buy coffee and beverages in order to better meet her customers' demands. She hopes her business runs smoothly and will help her to improve her family's living conditions and save money for her family's events and emergencies.

loans.use: to buy coffee and beverages for sale.

loans.name: Cristelita

texts.en:
As a married parent of three children, Cristelita works hard to support her family.

She has a restaurant business in the Philippines and also earns additional income from buying and selling dried coconut meat. Cristelita is borrowing 14,000 PHP through NWTF to buy additional ingredients for her restaurant.

In the past, Cristelita has sustained her business activities through 22 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy additional ingredients for her food production business.

loans.name: Nga

texts.en:
Nga, 64, is married with two sons. She lives with her sons and husband in Ho Chi Minh City. For five years, she and her husband have earned money to support their family by selling food to people in their community. 

Nga is requesting a loan to expand her business by buying meats and good quality ingredients to make better meals to satisfy her customers. She hopes her business runs smoothly and will generate a higher income to assist her in improving her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to buy meat and other ingredients to make meals for selling.

loans.name: Lucema

texts.en:
Lucema is a 37-year-old married woman and a mother of five young children. She is from Bohol, Philippines.  She and her husband have been engaged in a fishing business for almost seven years now. 

Lucema is asking for a loan in order to buy a new engine for their fishing boat.  With the new engine, her husband will be able to start fishing again.  Lucema hopes to expand their fishing business in the future.  Moreover, she also wants to save money for the schooling of her children.

loans.use: to buy a new engine for the fishing boat.

loans.name: Emelia

texts.en:
Emelia is 49 years old and she is from Gango, Ozamis City.  She is married and has three children. 

To earn a living, Emelia owns and operates a general store.  Emelia been engaged in her business for six years and earns 6,500 PHP each month for these activities. Emelia is requesting a loan of 30,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase new items such as candies, Milo (a brand of malted milk), shampoo, soaps, etc. to add to her inventory.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her business to improve her family’s general living conditions. 

In 2010, Emelia joined GDMPC.

loans.use: to purchase new items such as candies, Milo (malted milk), shampoo and soaps.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy fertilizers for the vegetable garden

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages

loans.name: Mariano

texts.en:
Mariano is a 45-year-old farmer and fisherman from Bohol, Philippines. He is a married man and a father of four children.

Mariano is asking for a loan to buy new fishing nets and fertilizer for the farm. With this, Mariano will be able to enhance his earning through his business.
In the future, Mariano aims to expand his business and save money for the schooling of his children.

loans.use: to buy new fishing nets and fertilizer for the farm

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy cow, sheep for a livestock business.

loans.name: Los 21 Quemados Group

texts.es:
Este Banco Comunal se llama “Los 21 Quemados” está conformado por 16 emprendedores quienes se dedican a diferentes rubros entre los cuales se encuentran; peluquería, amasandería, pastelería, venta de cuchuflis, venta de estructuras metálicas, almacén, venta de detergente, venta de ropa, bazar, venta de jabones, servicios entre otros. Todos ellos pertenecientes a la comuna de Conchalí, ubicada en la ciudad de Santiago.
Carolina, presidenta del grupo del Banco Comunal, quien en la foto se encuentra de pie, ocupando el quinto lugar de izquierda a derecha, viste polera y pantalón de color negro, su cabello es de color castaño oscuro y lo usa tomado.
Ella se dedica al rubro de la pastelería, desde hace 6 años. Comenta que trabaja en su casa todos los días y su horario lo distribuye de acuerdo a su disponibilidad. Por el momento trabaja con su marido ya que esta juntando dinero para comprarse unas maquinas para su negocio.
La mercadería e insumos que va necesitando la compra en lugares que se especializan en vender productos de pastelería a bajo costo, por lo tanto conveniente económicamente.
Con el crédito comprará una revolvedora, batidora y una sobadora.
Una de las metas de Carolina es continuar con su negocio y tener ventas al por mayor en pasteles y empanadas, así con esto generar mayores ingresos para optar a una mejor calidad de vida.
Carolina vive junto a su abuela, madre, tía, esposo y dos hijos de 7 y un año de edad. Sus sueños a nivel personal es viajar, y a nivel laboral tener un negocio fuera del país.
Ella está muy contenta y agradecida de la oportunidad brindada por Fondo Esperanza para invertir en su negocio. Además se siente muy cómoda con el grupo que participa, ya que son unidos y existe confianza.
Conchalí es una comuna de la región metropolitana (donde está Santiago, capital de Chile)  ubicada hacia el norte de la misma. Posee un barrio industrial delimitado, y múltiples actividades económicas y comerciales de pequeño tamaño, incluyendo ferias libres, talleres artesanales, garajes, terminales de buses, entre otros. El sector microempresarial es muy relevante en su actividad comercial.
texts.en:
This communal bank is called “Los 21 Quemados” and has 16 entrepreneurs who are in various lines of work among which are: barber shop, bakery, pastry shop, candy sales, metal shop, store, detergent sales, clothing sales, bazaar, soap sales and services, among others.  All are from Conchalí commune located in the city of Santiago.

Carolina is bank president and in the photo is standing fifth from left to right wearing black pants and shirt; her hair is dark brown and she’s wearing it gathered up.

She’s been making pastry for six years.  She comments that she works at home every day and distributes her schedule according to her availability.  For the movement, she works with her husband since he’s saving up money to buy some machinery for his business.

She buys her merchandise and ingredients as needed in places that specialize in selling pastry-making supplies at low cost which is advantageous economically.  She will use the loan to buy a mixer, a blender and a kneader.

One of Carolina’s goals is to continue in business and to sell cakes and turnovers at wholesale to earn higher income and be able to opt for a better quality of life.

Carolina lives with her grandmother, mother, aunt, husband and two children who are 7 and 1 year old.  Her dream on a personal level is to travel and on a business level is to have a business abroad.

She is very happy and grateful for the opportunity being provided by Fondo Esperanza to invest in her business and she also feels very comfortable in her group because they are very united and they trust each other.

Conchalí is a commune in the Santiago Metropolitan Region (where Santiago, Capital of Chile is located) located in the north part of it.  It has a specific industrial neighborhood and many economic activities, small businesses, book fairs, crafts shops, garages and bus terminals, among others.  The micro business sector is a big part of its economic activity.

loans.use: to buy a mixer, a blender and a kneader.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en: Marilyn is married with five children. She is 41 years old and lives in Canicapan, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. Marilyn owns and operates a plot of farm land, planting bananas to earn a living. She has been in this business for eight years and earns 3,000 PHP each month. She requested a loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase farm chemicals. Marilyn has been a member of Kiva's partner GDMPC since 2011. In the future, Marilyn's plan is to save her returns in order to improve her house.

loans.use: to purchase farm chemicals.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.

loans.name: Leona

texts.en:
Leona is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fishing business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 13000 through Kiva partner NWTF in order to buy additional fishing net and other fishing materials for her fishing business.

Leona has been in this business for 20 years. Leona earns more income from food vending.

Leona has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional fishing net and other fishing materials.

loans.name: Ester

texts.en:
This is Ester, 46, and a resident of Payatas, Philippines. She is married to Aldrin, a driver and she is mother to her children. She, together with her husband, manage their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Ester operates a rug-making business. She mainly offers rugs, from those round palm sized ones, to the much larger doormats and other crafts that most rug-makers make up every day. As rugs are a major part of Filipino housekeeping and cleaning, rugs are one of the most common products that can be bought, sometimes even from a peddler while you are riding in a speeding jeepney down the highway. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php20,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread and other materials for her business. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Ester hopes to give her children a good and quality education and dreams to expand her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for cloth, thread, needles, fabric and other materials needed in her business.

loans.name: Kamene

texts.en:
Kamene is 34 years-old, and a resident of Tiribe, Coast Province, Kenya. She is married with four children. She is a retailer who has been selling sniffing tobacco for the last five years. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses. 

Kamene is a very hard working person who despite her advanced age works to reach her goals. She is asking for this loan to buy more stock of tobacco.

loans.use: to buy more stock of tobacco.

loans.name: Nadr Group

texts.en:
The Nadr group consists of four ladies who live in Taiz, Yemen. Muna, a 23-year-old married mother of three, is a hardworking and responsible woman who sells many products including clothes, food, and incense. She has applied for a youth loan of 20000 YER to buy a cupboard for her house.

Muna hopes to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy a cupboard for her house.

loans.name: Esperanza Group

texts.es:
Este Banco Comunal se llama “Esperanza” está conformado por 16 emprendedores quienes se dedican a diferentes rubros, entre los cuales se dedican a diferentes rubros, entre los cuales se encuentran; venta de yerbas, venta de anillos, feriantes, servicios entre otros. Todos ellos pertenecientes a la comuna de Renca, ubicada en la ciudad de Santiago.
Katherine, integrante del grupo del Banco Comunal, quien en la foto se encuentra de pie en primera fila, ocupando el tercer lugar de derecha a izquierda, viste poleron de color negro, su cabello es de color castaño oscuro y lo usa tomado.
Ella se dedica al rubro de venta de articulos varios, desde hace 2 meses. Comenta  que trabaja en ferias libres y algunos días a la semana y su horario lo distribuye de acuerdo a su disponibilidad, ella vende articulos según la temporada, por el momento ofrece articulos para navidad.
La mercadería que va necesitando la compra en diferentes comercializadoras y distribuidoras donde encuentra variedad y novedad de articulos varios para vender a bajo costo, por lo tanto conveniente económicamente.
Con el crédito comprará pinches, ropa interior, juguetes, perfumes.
Una de las metas de Katherine es tener un negocio más grande y establecido donde pueda tener de todo para su clientela.
Katherine vive junto a su suegra y esposo y su futuro hijo que viene en camino. Sus sueños a nivel laboral tener un lindo negocio y amplio, y anivel familiar tener buenos ingresos para darle un buen pasar a su futuro hijo.
Ella está muy contenta y agradecida de la ayuda brindada por Fondo Esperanza para invertir en su negocio. Además se siente muy cómoda con el grupo del cual forma parte ya que tienen una muy buena comunicación.
Renca es una comuna ubicada en el sector norponiente del Santiago (capital de Chile), región metropolitana. Es una comuna con un fuerte trabajo comunitario, entre lo que se destaca el canal de televisión comunitario “Renca TV”, creado con el fin de promover las actividades culturales y artísticas de la comuna.
texts.en:
This communal bank is called “Esperanza” (Hope) and it has 16 entrepreneurs all with different lines of work among which are: tea sales, ring sales, street merchants and services, among others.  All are from the Renca commune located in the city of Santiago.

Katherine is a member of this communal bank and in the photo she appears in the first row, third from right to left, wearing a black shirt.  Her hair is dark brown and she wears it gathered up.

She has been selling varied merchandise for two months.  She comments that she works in the free street markets some days a week according to her availability; she sells items according to the season and for the moment is selling Christmas merchandise.

The merchandise she needs she buys from various stores and suppliers where she finds variety and novelty at low cost which is advantageous economically.  She will use the loan to buy pins, underwear, toys and perfume.

One of Katherine’s goals is to have a larger business set up so she can have everything for her customers.

Katherine lives with her mother-in-law and her husband and the future child she’s expecting.  Her dream at the business level is to have a nice, spacious shop and on the family level is to earn good income to provide well for her future child.

She is very happy and grateful for the support provided by Fondo Esperanza to invest in her business and she also feels very comfortable in her group because they communicate well.

Renca is a commune located in the northwest part of Santiago (capital of Chile) metropolitan region.  It’s a commune with strong community action among which stands out the “Renca TV” community television station that was created to promote the commune’s cultural and artistic activities.

loans.use: to buy hatpins, underwear, toys and perfume.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy merchandise such as clothing and shoes, and to buy kitchen utensils for her food business

loans.name: Judith

texts.en: Judith is a 40-year-old fish vendor from Ubay, Bohol. She has been engaged in the fish vending business for more than 20 years now. Judith is asking for a loan to buy more fish to sell. In the future, Judith hopes to expand her business and save money for the schooling of her children.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy a fruit cart.

loans.name: Dunstan

texts.en:
Dunstan is 25 years old, married, and the father of a two-year-old. His wife tends to the house, while he operates a boda-boda service. In business for six years, he earns a monthly income of Kshs. 20,000.

Dunstan is requesting his second loan from KADET LTD, having repaid his previous one. He intends to purchase another new motorbike so that he can hire someone and increase his profits. Dunstan plans to save the anticipated profits for his child's education.

loans.use: to buy another motorbike.

loans.name: Esperanza Y Fe De Lampa Group

texts.es:
Este Banco Comunal se llama “Esperanza y Fe de Lampa” está conformado por 16 emprendedores quienes se dedican a diferentes rubros entre los cuales se encuentran; venta de comida rápida, venta de berlines, venta a pan, venta de pasteles, taller de bicicletas, mecánico, venta de cojines, tejidos, servicios entre otros. Todos ellos pertenecientes a la comuna de Colina, ubicada en la ciudad de Santiago.
Clara, integrante del grupo del Banco Comunal, quien en la foto se encuentra de pie en  segunda fila, ocupando el segundo lugar de derecha a izquierda, viste chaqueta de color verde, usa aros de color gris, su cabello es de color castaño oscuro y lo usa tomado.
Ella se dedica al rubro de comida rápida, desde hace 6 años. Comenta que trabaja todos los días en las tardes, en la salida de su casa, ofreciendo sopaipillas, completos, papas fritas, además comenta que tiene 2 carritos para ofrecer su comida a su clientela.
La mercadería e insumos que va necesitando la compra en diferentes distribuidoras donde encuentra los productos de buena calidad a bajo costo por lo tanto conveniente económicamente.
Con el crédito comprará una pesa eléctrica, insumos como aceites, servilletas, papas, y cemento para terminar su local.
Una de las metas de Clara es terminar su local y poner sus maquinas y atender a su clientela, y además trabajar junto con su esposo e hijo, asi con esto generar mayores ingresos y darle un buen pasar a su familia.
Clara vive junto a su esposo y su hijo de 24 años de edad. Sus sueños a nivel laboral son tener su local lo más pronto posible y trabajar junto son su familia.
Ella está muy contenta y agradecida de la oportunidad brindada por Fondo Esperanza para invertir en su negocio. Además se siente muy cómoda con el grupo que participa.
Colina es una comuna de la región metropolitana (donde está Santiago, capital de Chile) ubicada al norte de la misma. Actualmente es centro de importantes inversiones, principalmente en el área agro industrial, debido a la instalación de grandes e importantes empresas, que de paso entregan un gran número de empleos a la comunidad. Es también un área de parcelaciones de agrado, lo que ha contribuido a aumentar considerablemente el número de habitantes. También cuenta con espacios adecuados al turismo, tales como termas, deporte en la Laguna Piedra Roja y montañismo.
texts.en:
This communal bank is called “Esperanza y Fe de Lampa” (Lampa Hope and Faith) and it has 16 members in a variety of lines of work like fast-food sales, donut sales, cake sales, bicycle repair shop, mechanic, cushion sales, knitting and services, among others.  All are from Colina commune in the city of Santiago.

Clara is a communal bank member and in the photo is standing in the second row, second from right to left, wearing a green jacket, gray earrings and her hair is dark brown and gathered up.

She’s been in the fast-food business for six years.  She comments that she works every day in the evening outside her house selling sopaipillas, hot-dogs, and fried potatoes.  She also comments that she has two carts she uses to offer her food to her clientele.  She buys supplies and merchandise as needed from various suppliers where she finds quality products at low prices which is economically advantageous.  She will use the loan to buy an electric scale, ingredients like oil, napkins, potatoes and cement to finish her locale.

One of Clara’s goals is to finish building her locale, install her equipment and tend to customers and also to work alongside her husband and her son in order to earn higher income to provide better well-being for the family.

Clara lives with her husband and 24-year-old son.  Her dream on a work level is to have her locale ready as soon as possible and to work together with her family.  She’s very happy with and grateful for the opportunity provided by Fondo Esperanza to invest in her business and she also feels very comfortable in her group.

Colina is a commune in the metropolitan region of Santiago (Capital of Chile) located in the northern sector.  It’s currently seat of important investments, especially in the industrial sector because large, important firms have settled here which provide a large number of employment opportunities for the community.  It’s also an area that’s been subdivided for housing which has contributed significantly to the increase in the number of residents.  It also has places that are attractive to tourism like thermal spas, sports in Piedra Roja Lagoon and mountaineering.

loans.use: to buy an electric scale, ingredients, napkins, potatoes and cement.

loans.name: Sunshine

texts.en:
This is Sunshine, 26 and a resident of Manila, Philippines. She is married to Richard, a dispatcher, and is a mother to her children. She, together with her husband, manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses and her children’s studies. 

Sunshine operates a buy and sell business. What she basically does is buy candy and toy products from wholesalers. She repacks them and sells them with a little profit. Her products are assorted candies, toys and other products of the like. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low selling prices and the many options she offers. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 300 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue the operations of her business, she is requesting a 15,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of candies and toy products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Sunshine dreams to give her children a good and quality education as well as hopes to get a good and permanent stall for her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, and this is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for more quantities of candies and toy products to expand her product inventory.
